channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Party of Japan’s Premier Poised for Big Election Win
item.description: Liberal Democrats and their coalition partner could control both houses, ending what is known here as a “twisted Parliament” that has added to Japan’s recent political paralysis.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: Inmate’s Letters Hint at North Korea Opening
item.description: The fact that Kenneth Bae, an American prisoner in North Korea, was allowed to send letters to his family suggests that the reclusive state is open to negotiations about him.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Europe’s Carrot-and-Stick Approach to Israel Includes Blacklisting Hezbollah
item.description: The decision to designate Hezbollah as a terrorist organization illustrated the European Union’s strategy of trying to rein in Israeli actions that undermine the Middle East peace process.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Kerry Achieves Deal to Revive Mideast Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Israel and the Palestinian Authority had agreed to join him in Washington in hopes of resuming formal talks for the first time since 2010.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, flew from Amman to Ramallah to meet with Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, on Friday.

item.title: The Lede: Chants of ‘Russia Without Putin’ Ring Out as an Activist Blogger Goes Down Tweeting
item.description: Protesters rallied in Moscow and St. Petersburg on Thursday after the activist blogger Aleksei Navalny was sentenced to five years in jail.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Nobuyuki Aihara, Olympic Champion, Dies at 78
item.description: Mr. Aihara won two gold medals at the 1960 Olympics in Rome and helped usher in an era of Japanese gymnastic dominance.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK
item.media:description: Nobuyuki Aihara, center, won the floor competition and helped Japan to an all-around gold medal at the 1960 Games in Rome.

item.title: Shame! A Taiwan Tennis Ace Flirts With China, and Big Money
item.description: Political insecurities have re-emerged over the possibility that Hsieh Su-wei, the first Taiwanese player to win a Grand Slam, could shift her allegiance to China as part of an endorsement deal.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Hsieh Su-wei, with Shuai Peng, in the women’s doubles final at Wimbledon this month. Hsieh’s father said her potential nationality swap was primarily about money.

item.title: The Lede: Cheers for Navalny in Court and Online
item.description: Supporters of the anti-corruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny, one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s most dogged opponents, celebrated his release from custody with applause in the courtroom and by sharing images of him online.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot from the blog of Aleksei Navalny, showing the Russian activist embracing his wife, Yulia, in court on Friday. At lower left, the logo of the state-owned Russia Today network was covered with a black square.

item.title: Judge Challenges White House Claims on Authority in Drone Killings
item.description: Judge Rosemary M. Collyer said she was “troubled” by the government’s assertion that it could kill American citizens it designated as dangerous with no role for judicial review.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen in 2008. He was among three Americans killed in drone strikes by the United States in 2011.

item.title: U.S., Urging Worker Safety, Outlines Steps for Bangladesh to Regain Its Trade Privileges
item.description: The administration released an “action plan,” pressing Bangladesh to significantly increase the number of labor, fire and building inspectors and to improve their training.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Berlusconi Associates Sentenced
item.description: Three associates of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi were sentenced to jail terms of five to seven years on Friday for aiding and abetting prostitution.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Bomb Explodes in Mosque
item.description: Suicide attacks, car bombings and other violence have killed nearly 200 people since Ramadan began last week.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Panama: Former Spy Returns to U.S.
item.description: Italy’s justice minister protested saying that the request for the extradition of the former C.I.A. officer, Robert Seldon Lady, based on an Interpol warrant, “has been disregarded without plausible explanations.”
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: U.S. Charges Algerian in Deadly Gas Plant Attack
item.description: Mokhtar Belmokhtar, who claimed responsibility for the January attack that killed three Americans, is being sought by prosecutors for a trial in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Mokhtar Belmokhtar in an undated video.

item.title: Accuser’s Sentence in Dubai Rape Case Stirs Anger in West
item.description: The case highlights the increasingly frequent tensions between the United Arab Emirates’ international atmosphere and its legal system, which is strongly influenced by Islamic traditions.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Crowds March in Egypt to Protest Morsi Detention
item.description: The United Nations commissioner for human rights said she asked the government to explain the legal basis for detaining the ousted president Mohamed Morsi, who has been incommunicado for weeks.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Conscientious Objector Poses a Challenge to the Israeli Military
item.description: Natan Blanc asked to be exempted from the draft over the Palestinian occupation, but after a trial and jail, the military said it was rejecting him.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The essential problem of the Palestinian’s life is not whether he’s being smiled at at the checkpoint,” said Natan Blanc.

item.title: In Pakistan, Police See Political Revenge Behind Poisoning Deaths
item.description: The police say that Arsal Khan Khichi turned a charity feast deadly, killing 20 people in a plot against a cousin who beat him in a local election.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Australia Adopts Tough Measures to Curb Asylum Seekers
item.description: A policy to deal with a record number of asylum seekers would deny permission to settle in the country to anyone who arrived by boat without a visa.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:description: An asylum seeker is rescued after a boat with 150 migrants, mostly Afghans, en route to Australia, sank off Indonesia's Java island in 2012.

item.title: G-20 Backs Plan to Curb Tax Avoidance by Large Corporations
item.description: The plan aims at corporations only and, if widely adopted, would shift some of the global tax burden away from small businesses and individuals.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and FLOYD NORRIS
item.media:description: Angel Gurria, secretary-general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, spoke about the agency's tax-avoidance proposal on Friday in Moscow.

item.title: Setbacks Rise In Prosecuting The President Of Kenya
item.description: The latest setbacks increased concerns that Uhuru Kenyatta will be freed of charges of crimes against humanity.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Uhuru Kenyatta is accused of crimes against humanity.

item.title: Leading Putin Critic Is Freed Pending Appeal After Protests
item.description: A day after his conviction on embezzlement charges incited protests, Aleksei A. Navalny was released from custody.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny embraced his wife, Yulia, on Friday after a judge released him from police custody.

item.title: Merkel Again Addresses U.S. Surveillance
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel had hoped to focus her re-election campaign on domestic priorities, but revelations of American surveillance programs are complicating those plans.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: At War Blog: Marines Share Frank Views With Hagel on Women in Combat
item.description: Fifteen female Marines sat down with Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel to discuss the Pentagon’s decision to integrate women into front-line combat positions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A female British soldier takes a break as Afghan tribal leaders complete prayers, at Camp Leatherneck in Helmand Province in 2012.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Panel to Study Vatican’s Finances and Transparency
item.description: Pope Francis has established a committee of seven lay experts and one cleric to help carry out “the simplification and rationalization” of the Vatican’s departments.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
